text: Useful Theorems and Facts in Number Thoery ◦ Divisibility: For integers a, b we say a | b if there exists integer c such that b = ac. Following are two useful tools with divisibility: (i) a | b, c | d ⇒ ac | bd, (ii) a | b, a | c ⇒ a | bx + cy ∀x, y ∈ Z Another useful fact is, a | b ⇒ |a| ≤ |b|. So, if x, y ∈ N and we need to show x = y then we may try showing x | y and y | x. This fact is also useful in some proofs by contradiction method. Euclid’s Lemma If a | bc with a, b coprime, then a | c. Division Algorithm Given integers a and b, with b > 0, there exist unique integers q and r satisfying a = bq + r (0 ≤ r < b). If a = bq + r then gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, r). Hence we can ﬁnd gcd(a, b) using the division algorithm taught in high schools. Using the steps of division algorithm, we can express gcd(a, b) as a linear combination of a and b, which give rise to the theorem (Bezout’s Theorem): Given integers a and b, not both zero, there exist unique integers x and y such that gcd(a, b) = ax + by. The last theorem has this consequences: Two integers a and b are coprime (i.e. gcd(a, b) = 1) if and only if there exist integers x, y such that 1 = ax + by. You can use Bezout’s theorem to prove Euclid’s lemma (above), or this following fact: a | c, b | c with gcd(a, b) = 1, then ab | c. Pitfalls a | c, b | c need not imply ab | c, e.g. 2 | 4, 4 | 4 does not imply 2·4 = 8 | 4. Another is, a | bc need not imply a | b or a | c, e.g. neither 10 | 4, nor 10 | 5, but 10 | 4 · 5 = 20. ◦ An useful theorem about equations like ax + by = c is: For a, b ∈ Z, the equation ax + by = c has a solution if and only if d | c where d = gcd(a, b). If x0, y0 is any particular solution then all solutions are given by x = x0 +(b/d)t, y = y0 −(a/d)t where t is any integer. ◦ Congruence: Congruence is just another notion of divisiblity. We write a ≡ b(mod n) if n | a − b. Properties like a ≡ b(mod n), c ≡ d(mod n) ⇒ ac ≡ bd(mod n) are straight-forward and we omit them here 1. Following are some facts which are often useful: (1) ∀ n ∈ Z, n 2 ≡ 0, 1(mod 3), n 2 ≡ 0, 1, 4(mod 5) and, for odd n ∈ Z, n 2 ≡ 1(mod 8) (2) For any n ∈ Z, n 3 ≡ 0, 1, −1(mod 7), n 3 ≡ 0, 1, −1(mod 9). (3) If n ≡ 3(mod 4) then ∃a prime p such that p|n and p ≡ 3(mod 4). (4) For a prime p and an integer n, p|n 2 + 1 only if p = 2 or p ≡ 1(mod 4). (5) If p is a prime that does not divide a, then there exists an unique integer x such that 1 ≤ x ≤ p − 1 and ax ≡ 1(mod p) . ◦ Another fact is, if P (x) be a polynomial with integer coeﬃcients, then for a, b, n ∈ Z, a ≡ b(mod n) ⇒ P (a) ≡ P (b)(mod n). This follows from the property that for any polynomial P (x) with integer coeﬃcients, a − b | P (a) − P (b) ∀ a, b ∈ Z. 1you may look up these things in the book ‘An Excursion in Mathematics’. 1 ◦ Fermat’s Theorem If p is a prime and a ∈ Z then ap ≡ a(mod p). In other words, if p ∤ a then ap−1 ≡ 1(mod p). ◦ Wilson’s theorem If p be a prime then (p − 1)! ≡ −1( mod p). Actually, we can show that n is prime if and only if (n − 1)! + 1 is divisible by n. ◦ Gauss introduced a function ϕ(n) = number of positive integers≤ n that are coprime to n. Then we have the following generalisation of Fermat’s theorem : aϕ(n) ≡ 1(mod n) ∀a ∈ Z : gcd(a, n) = 1. A function f : N → R is called a multiplicative function if f (mn) = f (m)f (n) for all m, n such that gcd(m, n) = 1. So if we evaluate f (pk) for all prime p and k ∈ N, then we can determine f (n) for any n ∈ N, thanks to fundamental theorem of arithmetic. It can be proved that ϕ(n) is multiplicative. And it is easy to see that ϕ(pk) = pk − pk−1. (The positive integers≤ pk that are not coprime to pk are precisely the numbers p, 2p, 3p, . . . , pk−1p.) Hence, if n = pa1 1 pa2 2 . . . p ak k be the prime factorisation of n then ϕ(n) = ϕ(pa1 1 )ϕ(pa2 2 ) . . . ϕ(pak k ) = n(1 − 1 p1 )(1 − 1 p2 ) . . . (1 − 1 pk ) . An interesting fact about ϕ is, ∑ d|n ϕ(d) = n. (The sum is over all divisors d of n) ◦ Theorem. If F (n) = ∑ d|n f (n) then F (n) is multiplicative iﬀ f (n) is multiplicative. ◦ For any n ∈ N, let τ (n) denote number of positive divisors of n and σ(n) denote the sum of all positive divisors of n. Note that τ (n) = ∑ d|n 1 and σ(n) = ∑ d|n d, by the theorem above, τ and σ are both multiplicative. Hence from prime factorisation of n you can easily ﬁnd τ (n) and σ(n) : τ (n) = (a1 + 1)(a2 + 1) . . . (ak + 1), σ(n) = (1 + p1 + p2 1 . . . + pa1 1 ) . . . (1 + pk + p2 k . . . + pak k ). ⋆ One important fact is, τ (n) is odd if and only if n is a perfect square. ◦ Representation of a positive integer: Fix any b ∈ N. Then any n ∈ N can be written uniquely as n = nsbs + ns−1bs−1 + . . . + n1b + n0 where 0 ≤ ni ≤ b − 1 for each i. ◦ Pythagorean Triples: If (x, y, z) satisﬁes x2 + y2 = z2, where x, y, z ∈ N, then we call it a pythagorean triple. Triples with gcd(x, y, z) = 1 are called primitive pythagorean triples (PPT). Theorem. If (x, y, z) is a PPT with y even, then there exists r, s ∈ N with r > s, gcd(r, s) = 1 and exactly one of r, s even, such that x = r2 − s2, y = 2rs, z = r2 + s2. (If y is odd then just swap the roles of x and y.) Note, the above formula generates only primitive Pythagorean triples, not all Pythagorean triples. For example, (6, 8, 10) is not of the form (r2 − s2, 2rs, r2 + s2).) ◦ Chinese Remainder Theorem: If m1, . . . , mk are pairwisely coprime integers and a1, . . . , ak are any integers then the system x ≡ a1( mod m1), x ≡ a2( mod m2), . . . , x ≡ ak( mod mk), has solution and any two solutions are congruent modulo m1m2 . . . mk. Further, there is a good way to ﬁnd a solution. Take M = m1m2 . . . mk and let m ′ k = M/mk. Then ﬁnd n1, n2, . . . , nk such that m ′ ini ≡ 1( mod mi), for each i. Then x = a1m ′ 1n1 + a2m′ 2n2 + . . . + akm′ knk is a solution of the system. 2 ◦ Some facts about greatest integer function: (a) 0 ≤ x − ⌊x⌋ < 1, (b) ⌊x + n⌋ = ⌊x⌋ + n for n ∈ Z, (c) ⌊x⌋ + ⌊y⌋ ≤ ⌊x + y⌋ ≤ ⌊x⌋ + ⌊y⌋ + 1. (d) ⌊x + 1/2⌋ is the integer nearest to x. If two integers are equidistant from x then it denotes the greater one. (e) ⌊x⌋ = ⌊x/2⌋ + ⌊(x + 1)/2⌋, for x > 0. (f) ⌊x⌋ + ⌊−x⌋ = 0 if x ∈ Z, −1 otherwise. In most of the cases, just writing the inequality x − 1 < ⌊x⌋ ≤ x helps. References: • An Excursion in Mathematics, • Problem Solving strategies (by Arthur Engel), • 104 Number Theory Problems. There are plenty of techniques and approaches to number theoretic problems appearing in competitive exams like olympiads. So try to practice as much problems as you can.
